revisions.rev:
{{lowercase|gNewSense}} {{ infobox OS | name = gNewSense | logo = [[Image:Gnewsenselogo.png|70px]] | screenshot = [[File:GNewSense screenshot.png|300px]] | caption = gNewSense | developer = Brian Brazil and Paul O'Malley | source_model = [[Free software]] | latest_release_version = 2.3 <ref>{{cite web |url=http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/gnewsense-users/2009-09/msg00090.html |title=[gNewSense-users] gNewSense 2.3 released |publisher=Lists.gnu.org |year=2009 |month=September |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> <!-- If you update this, remember to also update [[Comparison of Linux distributions]]--> | family = [[Unix-like]] | latest_release_date = {{release date and age|2009|09|14}} | latest_test_version = | latest_test_date = | kernel_type = [[Monolithic kernel|Monolithic]] [[Linux kernel]] | ui = [[GNOME]] | license = [[Free software]] licenses mainly the [[GNU GPL]] | working_state = dormant, according to DistroWatch<ref name="Distrowatch">{{cite web |url=http://distrowatch.com/table.php?distribution=gnewsense |title=DistroWatch.com: gNewSense |accessdate=2011-08-14}}</ref> | website = [http://www.gnewsense.org/ www.gnewsense.org] | supported_platforms = [[x86 architecture|x86]], [[MIPS architecture|mips]] | updatemodel = [[Advanced Packaging Tool|APT]] | package_manager = [[dpkg]] / [[Synaptic Package Manager]] }}
'''gNewSense''' is a [[Linux distribution]] based on [[Ubuntu (operating system) |Ubuntu]].<ref name="faq">{{cite web |url=http://www.gnewsense.org/index.php?n=FAQ.FAQ |title=gNewSense Official Website : Free as in freedom {{!}} FAQ / FAQ {{!}} browse |accessdate=2009-03-17 |work=gNewSense.org}}</ref> Its goal is to maintain the user-friendliness of Ubuntu, but with all [[proprietary software|proprietary]] (EG. [[binary blob]]s) and [[non-free]] software removed. The [[Free Software Foundation]] considers gNewSense to be a [[Linux distribution]] composed entirely of [[free software]].<ref>[http://www.gnu.org/distros/free-distros.html http://www.gnu.org/distros/free-distros.html] List of Free Software Foundation approved Linux distributions</ref>
gNewSense takes a relatively strict stance against proprietary software. For example, any documentation that gives instructions on installing proprietary software software is excluded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.gnewsense.org/Main/CommunityGuidelines |title=Community guidelines - gNewSense GNU/Linux |publisher=Wiki.gnewsense.org |date=2010-04-30 |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> gNewSense is the distribution used by [[Richard Stallman]] (founder and president of the [[Free Software Foundation]]) as of January 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://richard.stallman.usesthis.com/ |title=An interview with Richard Stallman |publisher=Richard.stallman.usesthis.com |date=2010-01-23 |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
The project was launched by Brian Brazil and Paul O'Malley in 2006. Since the 1.0 release, the Free Software Foundation assists gNewSense.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsf.org/news/gnewsense |title=gNewSense 1.0 released - Free Software Foundation |publisher=Fsf.org |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
With no releases in two years, on August 8, 2011, [[Distrowatch]] classified gNewSense as "dormant".<ref name="Distrowatch"/> == Technical aspects ==
By default gNewSense uses [[GNOME]], the official [[desktop environment]] of the [[GNU Project]]. The [[graphical user interface]] can be customized with the user's choice [[X display manager]], [[window managers]], and other desktop environments available to install through its hosted repositories.
The Ubiquity installer allows installing to the hard disk from within the [[Live CD]] environment without the need for restarting the computer prior to installation.
Besides standard system tools and other small applications, gNewSense comes installed with the following software: the [[OpenOffice.org]] productivity suite, the [[Epiphany (browser)|Epiphany]] Internet browser, the [[Pidgin (software)|Pidgin]] instant messenger, and the [[GIMP]] for editing photos and other [[raster graphics]]. Common [[software development]] tools including [[GNU Compiler Collection|GCC]] and the [[GNU Emacs]] [[text editor]] are installed by default.
=== Installation === The [[Live CD]] can be used to run the Operating System and to install onto disk. CD images are available for download.<ref>[http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/Download Download stable gNewSense]</ref>
=== Versions === Version 1.0, "deltad", was released on 2 November 2006 and was based on Ubuntu 6.06 "Dapper Drake". Version 2.0, "deltah", followed on 30 April 2008 and is based on Ubuntu 8.04 "Hardy Heron"; version 2.1 is a minor update which removes non-free software and expands hardware support. Version 3.0 is expected to be based on [[Debian]] instead of Ubuntu.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gnewsense.org/index.php?n=FAQ.FAQ#toc13 |title=FAQ - gNewSense GNU/Linux |publisher=Gnewsense.org |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
== Comparison with other distributions == Non-free software [[software repository|repositories]] are not provided by the gNewSense project, most non-free documentation and artwork have been removed and Ubuntu's "Universe" package repository is enabled by default. In order to avoid [[trademark]] problems that stem from the modification of [[Mozilla Firefox]], gNewSense 1.1 rebranded it as "BurningDog". BurningDog likewise neither suggests nor provides/supports non-free [[Plug-in (computing)|plugin]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/PressRelease20070122 |title=gNewSense Official Website | Main / PressRelease20070122 |publisher=Gnewsense.org |date=2007-01-22 |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> for various web media, such as [[Adobe Flash]]. gNewSense 2.0 uses the [[Epiphany (browser)|Epiphany]] web browser as released by the [[GNOME]] Project, with an option in software sources to install [[GNU IceCat]]. [[Debian]] is another Linux distribution noted for strict licensing requirements. gNewSense excludes non-free software that Debian includes (such as proprietary [[firmware]]) and does not have repositories for non-free software (which Debian has). It should be noted, however, that gNewSense's policies allow including documentation that the Debian project considers non-free, particularly that licensed under the [[GNU Free Documentation License]] with invariant sections. This includes many manuals and documentation released by the [[GNU project]] themselves.
== Limitations == Over one hundred pieces of non-free [[firmware]] were removed from the Ubuntu [[Linux kernel]] to make gNewSense.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Such removals include support for some [[wireless network]] cards, and therefore gNewSense currently supports a reduced range of wireless network cards compared to some other [[Linux distributions]]. By May 1, 2008, [[3D graphics]] and application support were also removed <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gnewsense.org/Main/Deltah |title=Main/Deltah - gNewSense GNU/Linux |publisher=Gnewsense.org |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> because of licensing issues<ref>[http://bugs.gnewsense.org/Bugs/00129 xserver-xorg: wordy SGI license may not be free] bugs.gnewsense.org</ref> with [[Mesa 3D (OpenGL)|Mesa 3D]]. After January 13, 2009, those issues were resolved and 3D support is now standard as of the 2.2 release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsf.org/blogs/licensing/2009-01-xorg-glx |title=3D graphics are 100% free software â Free Software Foundation â working together for free software |publisher=Fsf.org |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
=== Creating personalized versions === Brian Brazil developed a tool called Builder to make gNewSense from Ubuntu. It is designed to be general enough so that anyone can use it to make their own free software distribution of Linux.
{{See also|Software remastering}}
